text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Then the other twenty percent depending on sort of other plans you might have, you’ll probably end up spending about five thousand dollars. Huh, then you’ll go into the donut and then you don’t have to pay the rest of that. Patient: Well, they said the, huh, supplement plan that I’ve got now, I shouldn’t have to pay nothing out of pocket. Family Member: For normal trials. Patient: For normal things. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. I hope that’s true. But my experience with these really expensive drugs is you’re going to get billed. Patient: Right. I was thinking the same thing. Doctor: Okay? So they will ask you then at our pharmacy, well, can you afford that amount of money, and if you can’t, so they will work to see if there’s grants to see whether they can, the drug companies who make these drugs, can cover the cost that you can’t cover. Okay? But you have to have Medicare D and all these other things. So it can take a little bit while depending on if they have it. And again, they’re going to do a wallet check to see how much you make to see what they think you can cover. Patient: Well, I’m working. Family Member: Well, right. Doctor: That, that’s just the rules that they’re going to go through.

text: Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo?

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, there’s a, there’s a couple of trials that are in the works that might be specifically suited for you Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because of this mutation. Patient: So, we’re not, not doing standard of care. Doctor: Right.

text: Patient: Well and… Doctor: Here’s the thing you got to take the medication. Patient: You want me to start to take a look at the Norco again or? Doctor: I think you should and just don’t let it get out of control you know, like I’d rather you take it occasionally or all the time if you need to. There’s no right or wrong on that. Family Member: It’s not that bad. Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. So if you know for example, you’re just having a hard time sleeping, then just take your Norco at night so that way you can get a good night’s rest. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you know listen at night I’m not bothered I sleep like a rock, then take it when you first get up so that you can function. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Or you get up and it’s tolerable but now it’s the early afternoon, you still have more stuff to do, you’ve got family, you’ve got friends, there’s a barbeque, so take some, just a small amount… Patient: Sure.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
